body: I guess one possible solution is for me to just move all of my source code down by one directory? i.e. make a directory `<model>/code/package` and place both `dir_one` and `dir_two` under `/code/package`.. that would fix this error

Isn't a top-level definition considered an external namespace declaration? I've always been in the habit of: 
* Placing internal-facing namespace declarations behind internal paths (as you referenced in your self-answer). That's definitely a recommended action.
* Never introduce namespace collisions by 'shadowing' public names of modules (do you need your internal module to be called 'redis'? That might not be the best course of action.)

@BenWilson2 I'm actually not convinced that this is resolved or that MLflow is doing the right thing here. Take this traceback I'm seeing 

```
 File "/opt/ml/model/code/application_package/__init__.py", line 9, in <module>
    from .core import (  # noqa: F401
  File "/opt/ml/model/code/application_package/core.py", line 10, in <module>
    from operators.workflows import WorkflowDAG
  File "/opt/ml/model/code/operators/workflows.py", line 6, in <module>
    import networkx as nx
  File "/miniconda/envs/custom_env/lib/python3.8/site-packages/networkx/__init__.py", line 98, in <module>
    import networkx.utils
  File "/miniconda/envs/custom_env/lib/python3.8/site-packages/networkx/utils/__init__.py", line 2, in <module>
    from networkx.utils.decorators import *
  File "/miniconda/envs/custom_env/lib/python3.8/site-packages/networkx/utils/decorators.py", line 14, in <module>
    from decorator import decorator
  File "/opt/ml/model/code/api_utils/decorator.py", line 3, in <module>
    from fastapi import APIRouter, FastAPI, Request
```

My code is structured as follows

```
mlflow-issue-test
├── code
│   ├── api_utils
│   │   ├── decorator.py
│   │   └── __init__.py
│   └── operators
│       ├── workflows.py
│       └── __init__.py
├── conda.yml
├── data
└── MLmodel
```

Now `workflows.py` does `import networkx`, and `networkx` has a call `from decorator import decorator` (hoping to import the built-in `decorator` utility that ships with Python), this is error'ing out because it's finding *my* `decorator.py` that's under `code/api_utils` directory in my code.

This issue doesn't normally arise because the only way for anyone to access my `decorator.py` is to do `from api_utils import decorator`, but because MLflow adds every directory under `/code` to the PATH, I'm now seeing a conflict. 

Can you explain the logic for why MLflow is doing this in the first place? Your suggestion for putting all of my code under one global namespace wouldn't make a difference here.. imagine that I had this scenario

```
mlflow-issue-test
├── code
│   ├── my_module
│   │   ├── decorator
│   │    |    |── decorator.py
│   │    |    |── __init__.py
├── conda.yml
├── data
└── MLmodel
```

(I moved my code under `my_module` but now have a directory called `decorator` under `my_module`. I've namespaced all my code, but if an external package was doing `from decorator import decorator`, it would conflict with my code because MLflow has placed `/code/my_module/decorator` on the PYTHONPATH.

There was actually totally a bug in 1.24.0 on [this line](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/v1.24.0/mlflow/pyfunc/utils.py#L23) that caused models to work because MLflow wasn't actually detecting directories under `/code`. Once upgrading to 1.26.1, now our models break because MLflow is mucking with the system path so much

@jhallard Thank you for raising this issue! I completely agree that the conflict with `from decorator import decorator` is a pretty egregious bug. Ideally, I think it would be sufficient to add the model's `code` directory (instead of every directory recursively) to the PYTHONPATH, then `from api_utils import decorator` would work properly. Let me know what you think here. Would you be interested in contributing this fix?

Yup! And we can confirm that it's the right fix because that's what we were inadvertently doing in version==1.24.0 because of a bug where weren't detecting any of the directories as directories, which left the code such that none of the subdirectories were added on the PYTHONPATH. It's only after that bug was fixed, and the code started working as intended, that these bugs were introduced.

I'm definitely happy to contribute here, but I think it's going to be as simple as just deleting the logic of adding subdirectories?
Perfect! Yep, I agree that this is the right fix. Simply deleting the subdirectory logic should do the trick. Thank you so much - very excited about this contribution!

It seems like this might break some existing models out there that expect those subdirectories to already be on the path, for example, this is the issue that caused the bug to be fixed in the first place: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/issues/5786

If I undo that logic, this person's model will break with a `module not found` error. How should that person structure their `sklearn` model with external dependencies such that there's won't break?

Posted a comment here https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/issues/5786 to try and figure out how to fix this for everyone. We might need to change the way that `sklearn` and others use the `code_paths` argument when logging a model

I wouldn't worry too much about things breaking if someone is relying on recursive path additions to all scoped namespaces. That's definitely not correct. Thanks for continuing to dig in to this! If they have an issue, we can respond with referencing this ticket to elucidate why it's definitely not correct to recursively add all subpaths (I imagine anything named 'utils' or 'tools' or 'config' would blow up!). 
Please let us know when your PR is filed so we can get it in for the 2.0 release. 
Thanks again!

@BenWilson2 sounds good, but just one point of clarity - the code today isn't recursively adding paths, it's just going down level which is enough to cause things to blow up in most cases. This feels like some sort of directory structure off-by-one error
